Detailed Description

Is able to draw any kind of image inside the given boundaries of the drawable object. Per default the image box tries to buffer the image and does the decoding in a separate thread, so that the GUI is never blocked even when decoding large images.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

ImageBox::ImageBox (   ) 
 

If the default constructor is used, the parameters have to be provided by using the method Init.

ImageBox::ImageBox (  Control *  control,
const BitmapRes *  bitmap = 0
) 
 

Parameters:
control Parent control where the ImageBox is embedded.
bitmap Bitmap which should be drawn. Usually the drawing of a bitmap is faster then drawing an image which might require a complex decoding.

ImageBox::ImageBox (  Control *  control,
const ImageObtainer &  obtainer,
XYDIM  width = -1,
XYDIM  height = -1,
BOOLEAN  autostart = TRUE,
BOOLEAN  buffering = TRUE,
BOOLEAN  cleanup_buffer = FALSE
) 
 

Parameters:
control Parent control where the ImageBox is embedded.
obtainer Image obtainer which contains the image. The obtainer will be released in the destructor of the image box. Note that each image box requires to have a custom image object. This means that one image object may not be shared by several image boxes, otherwise the decoding might fail. If the application does not know whether the image is already obtained by another image box, it is recommended to create a custom image object by using BinData::Clone and pass this clone to the ImageFactory for creating a new image instance.
width User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
height User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
autostart If set to FALSE, animations (e. g. a GIF-animation) won't start automatically. In this case ImageBox::Start has to be invoked per hand.
buffering If set to TRUE (= default value) the image will be decoded once into a buffer, so that it can be drawn in a fast way. The decoding is done in a separate thread, so that the GUI won't be blocked. If set to FALSE, no buffering will be done and the image is decoded on every redraw in the context of the application. This reduces the memory demand but might block the GUI and is a lot slower as when using the buffer. A note to animations having a lot of frames (e. g. a GIF-animation): if the buffering is turned on, APOXI tries to buffer all frames. If this is not possible, at least 2 frame buffers are required to display the animation in a correct manner. If only 2 buffer are available, the current frame has to be decoded each time before drawing, hence the drawing might be slower but it still will be correct. If there is not enough memory for at least 2 buffers and the buffering is turned on, no image will be displayed. Note that turning off the buffering for GIF-images results in drawing only the current frame, which might lead to wrong results when having GIF-animations with transparent colors.
cleanup_buffer If set to TRUE, the buffer will be freed automatically as soon as the image box boundaries are outside the client area of it's parent control. This parameter is only respected if buffering has been set to TRUE.

INT ImageBox::GetFrame (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns:
returns the actual displayed frame number.

Bitmap * ImageBox::GetImageBuffer (  INT  frame_idx  )  const
 

Allows to get the buffered frame of an image. This might be only useful when the image buffering has been turned on. 0 is returned, if no buffer is available.

Parameters:
frame_idx Index of the desired frame.
Returns:
Buffered Bitmap.

const ImageObtainer& ImageBox::GetImageObtainer (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns:
Returns the ImageObtainer containing an Image.

Returns:
Returns the ImageObtainer containing the image.

DeviceContext::TransformationMode ImageBox::GetTransformation (   )  const [inline]

void ImageBox::Init (  Control *  control,
const ImageObtainer &  obtainer,
XYDIM  width = -1,
XYDIM  height = -1,
BOOLEAN  autostart = TRUE,
BOOLEAN  buffering = TRUE,
BOOLEAN  cleanup_buffer = FALSE
) 
 

Parameters:
control Parent control where the ImageBox is embedded.
obtainer Image obtainer which contains the image. The obtainer will be released in the destructor of the image box. Note that each image box requires to have a custom image object. This means that one image object may not be shared by several image boxes, otherwise the decoding might fail. If the application does not know whether the image is already obtained by another image box, it is recommended to create a custom image object by using BinData::Clone and pass this clone to the ImageFactory for creating a new image instance.
width User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
height User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
autostart If set to FALSE, animations (e. g. a GIF-animation) won't start automatically. In this case ImageBox::Start has to be invoked per hand.
buffering If set to TRUE (= default value) the image will be decoded once into a buffer, so that it can be drawn in a fast way. The decoding is done in a separate thread, so that the GUI won't be blocked. If set to FALSE, no buffering will be done and the image is decoded on every redraw in the context of the application. This reduces the memory demand but might block the GUI and is a lot slower as when using the buffer. A note to animations having a lot of frames (e. g. a GIF-animation): if the buffering is turned on, APOXI tries to buffer all frames. If this is not possible, at least 2 frame buffers are required to display the animation in a correct manner. If only 2 buffer are available, the current frame has to be decoded each time before drawing, hence the drawing might be slower but it still will be correct. If there is not enough memory for at least 2 buffers and the buffering is turned on, no image will be displayed. Note that turning off the buffering for GIF-images results in drawing only the current frame, which might lead to wrong results when having GIF-animations with transparent colors.
cleanup_buffer If set to TRUE, the buffer will be freed automatically as soon as the image box boundaries are outside the client area of it's parent control. This parameter is only respected if buffering has been set to TRUE.

XYDIM  width = -1,

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsBufferAvailable (  XYDIM  scaled_width,
XYDIM  scaled_height,
INT  frame_count
)  [static]
 

Allows to check, if ImageBox is able to buffer a certain Image. Width, height and frame count will be used to determine, if enough memory is available

Parameters:
scaled_width Desired width of image
scaled_height Desired height of image
frame_count Number of frames
Returns:
returns TRUE, if the ImageBox can buffer the desired Image. FALSE if not enough memory is available. In this case, another ImageBox has to release it's buffers to free memory.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsBufferingEnabled (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns TRUE, if the image buffering is enabled. Note that this does not mean, that the current image could be buffered. See ImageBox::GetImageBuffer for details.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsDecoding (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns TRUE, if the image is currently decoded. Usually it is not needed to care about this information. If providing a progress information, the window containing the image box can listen to the message ImageDecodingProgressMsg.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsDecodingFinished (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns TRUE, if the decoding of the image has been finished. Usually it is not needed to care about this information. If providing a progress information, the window containing the image box can listen to the message ImageDecodingProgressMsg.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsInstanceOf (  INT  id  )  const [virtual]
 

See also:
Component::IsInstanceOf

Reimplemented from DrawableObject.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsPlayOnceEnabled (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns TRUE, if an image containing more than one frame should be played only once. Per default FALSE is returned which means that a cyclic animation is done when having images with more than one frame.

See also:
ImageBox::Start

BOOLEAN ImageBox::IsPreviewShown (   )  const [inline]
 

Returns TRUE, if the preview of the image during decoding is shown. Per default TRUE is returned. When the progress of decoding is 0, FALSE is returned as a preview of an empty image only results in unnecessary flickering.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::OnMessage (  const Message &  msg  )  [protected, virtual]

void ImageBox::Restart (   ) 
 

Restarts an animation starting with the first frame.

void ImageBox::SetBitmap (  const BitmapRes *  bitmap,
XYDIM  width = -1,
XYDIM  height = -1
) 
 

After initializing an ImageBox, the bitmap can be exchanged with SetBitmap. On redraw the new given bitmap will be drawn. If no width or height is given, the Bitmap size will be used.

Parameters:
bitmap Bitmap which should be drawn.
width User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
height User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.

void ImageBox::SetBufferingEnabled (  BOOLEAN  buffering  )  [inline]
 

Enables the image buffering for the next decoding process.

void ImageBox::SetImageObtainer (  const ImageObtainer &  obtainer,
XYDIM  width = -1,
XYDIM  height = -1,
BOOLEAN  buffering = TRUE
) 
 

After initializing an ImageBox, the image obtainer containing an image can be exchanged.

Parameters:
obtainer Image obtainer which contains the image. The obtainer will be released in the destructor of the image box. Note that each image box requires to have a custom image object. This means that one image object may not be shared by several image boxes, otherwise the decoding might fail. If the application does not know whether the image is already obtained by another image box, it is recommended to create a custom image object by using BinData::Clone and pass this clone to the ImageFactory for creating a new image instance.
width User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
height User specific width. If -1 is used, the width of the image is used.
buffering If set to TRUE (= default value) the image will be decoded once into a buffer, so that it can be drawn in a fast way. The decoding is done in a separate thread, so that the GUI won't be blocked. If set to FALSE, no buffering will be done and the image is decoded on every redraw in the context of the application. This reduces the memory demand but might block the GUI and is a lot slower as when using the buffer. A note to animations having a lot of frames (e. g. a GIF-animation): if the buffering is turned on, APOXI tries to buffer all frames. If this is not possible, at least 2 frame buffers are required to display the animation in a correct manner. If only 2 buffer are available, the current frame has to be decoded each time before drawing, hence the drawing might be slower but it still will be correct. If there is not enough memory for at least 2 buffers and the buffering is turned on, no image will be displayed. Note that turning off the buffering for GIF-images results in drawing only the current frame, which might lead to wrong results when having GIF-animations with transparent colors.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::SetProperty (  ResourceParser &  parser,
const GuiObjectFactory::PropertyId  prop_id
) 
 

Initializes the instance by reading out a resource file generated by ARAGON. This method may not be invoked by the MMI in a direct manner and might be changed in future releases.

Reimplemented from DrawableObject.

BOOLEAN ImageBox::SetTransformation (  DeviceContext::TransformationMode  transformation  ) 
 

Applies a given transformation on the image. This will only work if buffering is enabled.

Parameters:
transformation Desired transformation, see DeviceContext::TransformationMode for details.
Returns:
FALSE if transformation is not applicable due to missing image buffers.

void ImageBox::Start (  BOOLEAN  play_only_once = FALSE  ) 
 

Starts playback of an animation. If image contains only one frame nothing is done.

Parameters:
play_only_once If set to TRUE the animation will be played only once independant from the repeat count given by the image itself (this might be useful if a GIF animation should be played only once although the repeat count from the image is bigger). If set to FALSE the repeat count from the image is respected.

void ImageBox::Stop (   ) 
 

Stops an animation and resets the actual frame to the first frame.
